Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Topographic Change and Cascading Hazards Following the Mw7.8 Kaikoura (New Zealand) Earthquake
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project will examine the effects of the November 13, 2016, series of earthquakes in the Kaikoura region of New Zealand on faulting and landslide processes. The focus of the effort will be to develop a digital elevation model and time series for this event and conduct field work to evaluate the remote sensing products. The work will complement other urgent response efforts underway in New Zealand following the earthquakes. It will enhance international collaboration among scientists in the United States and New Zealand and meaningfully involve students in the scientific research process.

The 4D evolution of topography is critical for understanding faulting and landslide processes. For major events that deform and erode landscapes, such as earthquakes, we lack data at an event scale for understanding such processes because of the prohibitive cost of repeat land and airborne surveys. Existing high-resolution topographic surveys tend to be small in geographic extent, and thus the chance of catching an area before an event is rare and usually limited in scope. However, recent advances in high performance computing coupled with stereo-satellite imagery collection create the opportunity to provide regional scale data that can be processed for high-resolution topography. Such surveys can potentially be repeated with modest resources such that a topographic time series data can be created quickly and relatively inexpensively. Per contracts with the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency and supercomputer centers, the PIs will gain access to the existing stereo imagery and super computer processing time needed to immediately develop and deliver a pre-event, high resolution digital elevation model to all researchers working on this event. This work will contribute to the understanding of landslide hazards after major earthquakes involving complex, multi-fault source mechanisms, and will be readily exportable to the scientific response of other earthquakes at other plate boundary settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regional assessment of landsliding and infrastructure damage in the aftermath of large earthquakes is severely limited by access and resources. Typically, roads are blocked and airborne transportation is the only viable means of assessment, yet these resources are in short supply due to rescue efforts. Additional limitations, including lack of connectivity, power, or infrastructure damage and loss of life, impact our ability to collect perishable data about land surface change and infrastructure damage.  The time period of days to weeks following an earthquake is critical because the fidelity of the data rapidly declines. Satellite-based photogrammetry methods using high-resolution stereo imagery potentially provide an avenue to rapidly assess land surface changes and infrastructure damage immediately following large earthquakes. 

 

The November 14th 2016 Mw7.8 Kaikoura earthquake in New Zealand has provided an unprecedented dataset on which to base evaluation of satellite derived surface models for measuring ground surface changes that are relevant to hazard mitigation. Our NSF award allowed us to apply an open-source algorithm (SETSM) to process raw stereo satellite imagery into high resolution (2 m and 0.5 m) digital surface models representing the land surface before and after the earthquake. The results of the analyses were compared against other means of generating digital elevation models, such as camera-equipped UAVs and Light Detection and Ranging. The satellite-based 3D data were analyzed to measure landscape change associated with immediate effects of the earthquake: how faults move in three dimensions and how the landscape is altered due to tens of thousands of landslides. This opportunity provided a unique test case of various methods to capture time-sensitive land surface information because high-resolution imagery was available from both before the earthquake as well as after. We envision that in the near future, such availability will be common and the developed techniques will be employed for future events of great societal and economic impact.
